Easy holiday shopping Holiday shoppers don't have to fight the mall crowds if they don't want to - here are a couple of other options: • Through 4:30 p.m. Friday, Dec. 6. West Middle School is hosting a "Media Marketplace" in the school's media center. West is located at 44401 W. Ann Arbor Trail in Plymouth Township. The marketplace will be open 7-9 p.m. Thursday, Dec. 5. Shoppers will be able to purchase books, computer software, family videos and compact discs. All profits go to the West media center. Sponsors include Scholastic Books and Little Professor on the Park, the I-CARE Committee, Sheldon Video, and Repeat the Beat. For more information, call Judith Pavitt at (313) 416-7612. • Meanwhile, over at Canton's Summit on the Park, gift certificates are being offered for sale which can be used toward the community center's programs or for a "Day at the Summit." Call the chamber at (313) 453-4040 or Glinski at (318) 454- 9970 for more information. & THURSDAY, DECEMBER 5,1996 • CANTON, MICHIGAN • 44 PAGES Blaze leaves family in cold BY VALERIE OLANDER STAFF WRITER The season of giving took on a new meaning for members of a Canton family who were burned out of their home during an accidental fire early Saturday morning. This holiday season, they will have to be recipients of others' good deeds. All five members of the Seaton family escaped from the 3:45 a.m. blaze unharmed, but with only the clothes on their back. The fire ravaged their Heritage Street home in the Palmer apd Haggerty area. "Neighbors pitched inland gave us clothes. Between all of them, we all have shoes that fit," said David Seaton. His wife, Kelly, said they returned to their home the next day and rummaged through the debris. They were able to find David's driver's license and a credit card. "They were charred around the edges, but (the store) took them any- way," Kelly said. Canton firefighters reached into their Canton Firefighters No. 2289 Charity Foundation fund to help pay for hotel expenses for the family until other living arrangements are made. On Monday, firefighter Mike Caruso presented David and Kelly with a check for $500. "One of the reasons we have it is to help families and people in tragedies like this," said Caruso. "Their home was gutted and they were burned out without any material possessions whatsoever." In the midst of the devastating loss, the Seaton family counted their blessings that they all made it of the burning house alive. Firefighters said the fire reached temperatures of between 1200 to 1500 degrees judging by the metal high beam that expanded from the massive heat. The floor collapsed in several rooms, including that of See BLAZE, A6 State cops challenge lower speed BY VALERIE OLANDER STAFF WRITER The Michigan State Police are geared to go to the state Attorney General's Office to enforce a traffic control order of 40 mph on Morton Taylor, between Saltz and Ford Road. Canton Township officials concurred with Wayne County Executive Edward McNamara on Nov. 12 and agreed to lower the speed limit to 25 mph without consensus of the state police. The decision was based on a provision of the law that allows the county road commission — or road department as in Wayne County's case — and township to reduce the speed limit to not less than 15 mph on roads adjacent to a park. The half-mile stretch of Morton Taylor dead-ends at Flodin Park. However, it appears state police won't be conceding. Residents pushed for the lower limit after a bicyclist was killed after being struck by a van Sept. 9. The van was driving within the posted 40 mph limit, according to Canton Police. "There has been a traffic control order (TCO) for some STAN PHOTO BY BILL BKXSLO time on Morton Taylor for 40 mph. The TCO has not been changed, even though some authority within Wayne County decided to post a temporary 25 mph sign. This is contrary to what state law says in the motor vehicle code," said Sgt. Jeff Corbit of the state police, Northville Post. An 85 percentile speed study conducted in late September determined vehicles were traveling an average of 41 mph on Morton Taylor, said Corbit. Sgt. Bill Brandt of the Lansing state police post is nowhandling the case. "Right now there's basically a TCO being ignored. I don't think the local authority has a right to supersede," he said. Several Morton Taylor residents and their attorney Marc Susselman said the provision of the law that, takes into account the close vicinity of the park will win out in the end. Resident John Irvin said the "temporary" sighs have already been taken down and that's an inkling that the 25 mph limit is in process of becoming official.
